bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Paul L. Tate, July 24, 1956

div1.p: Hench is disappointed the Lambert bill passed before he could meet with the committee. He is sure the next Congress will pass a resolution regarding Ames' contribution. He states that Lambert has made indiscretions and distortions in presenting the yellow fever story.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Paul L. Tate, July 24, 1956
div1.opener:
July 24, 1956
Mr. Paul L. Tate
1530 Tyler Street
Berkeley, California
My dear Mr. Tate:
div1.p:
I have just returned from Europe and find that a lot happened with respect
to Lambert et al, while I was away. I note that the committee had the
hearing even before they received my material. This disappointed me greatly
because I dictated the material before the date given me by Mr. Darden, the
Executive Assistant and, presumably, my material should have reached them
before they acted. However I realize that congressional committees are
sometimes erratic and bring up bills before expected dates; there is
nothing that I could have done about it as apparently the matter happened
while I was enroute to Europe.

On returning home, I find many letters from the congressmen and others to
whom I wrote, all telling me that the Lambert bill was passed, all regretting
that they had not known earlier of Doctor Ames, and all promising that they
would help me get the same honor for Doctor Ames at the next session of
Congress. I haven't the slightest doubt that this will go through and
indeed I intend to see that it does go through. If necessary, I will visit
Washington and, indeed, I will request permission to be heard by the ap-
propriate committees of the House and Senate. It would be ridiculous to
have the nurse honored and not the physician, Doctor Ames. I shall not
stop until this matter is corrected.

My feelings about Mr. Lambert were quite mixed. Frankly, in many ways he
has been a “naughty boy,” and I had to forgive him for saying many things,
some of which were indiscretions, some distortions and some were misunder-
standings or frank untruths. I am speaking from the record and have a
record of these things and will send you one before the next session of
Congress. The incongruity was that, having said some very nasty things
about Walter Reed as well as about Kean and others, he nevertheless wanted
to receive the “Walter Reed Honor,” as it were. Many of his accusations of
General Kean were completely false and could be very easily proven so by
the official records but when I called these to his attention, he refused
to accept them. I have no desire to defend General Kean, if and when he
made mistakes, even serious mistakes, but certainly the accusations which
Lambert made were ridiculous because the official Army records, available
to anyone, showed that Kean wasn't even in the position or in the station where
Lambert said he was when he was supposed to have done certain things un-
favorable to Doctor Ames.

For example, Major Kean had nothing whatever to do with Doctor Ames'
transfer from the station hospital. My reaction was that if the govern-
ment could forgive Hanberry (who, as you know, deserted) and later honor
him for a previous distinction, I would of course have to forgive Lambert
for his intensities and indiscretions because he certainly deserved very
real honor for what he did as of course does Doctor Ames, but more of this
later.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
cc: Mrs. Ames
